title: T. G. Vawdrey
text:
Theophilis Glascott Vawdrey (1850 – 23 October 1940) <a href="L.R.C.P.">L.R.C.P.</a>, <a href="M.R.C.S.">M.R.C.S.</a> was an English <a href="physician">physician</a>, surgeon and <a href="anti-vivisection">anti-vivisection</a> activist.
Vawdrey was born at <a href="St%20Austell">St Austell</a>, Cornwall. He was educated at <a href="Epsom%20College">Epsom College</a> (1862–1869) and received his medical education at <a href="University%20College%20Hospital">University College Hospital</a>. In 1872, he was awarded a certificate in dental surgery from the university. 
Vawdrey qualified M.R.C.S in 1873 and L.R.C.P. in 1874. He practiced medicine in Lewisham and was a surgeon for the Royal Kent Dispensary, Greenwich. 
Vawdrey built an extensive private practice in <a href="Plymouth">Plymouth</a>. He was the first honorary surgeon of the Plymouth and District Ambulance Service. He was elected an honorary life membership of the <a href="St.%20John%20Ambulance%20Association">St. John Ambulance Association</a>. In the 1890s, Vawdrey was Stipendiary Medical Officer for the Devon and Cornwall Homeopathic Dispensary. Vawdrey was a <a href="Conservatism">conservative</a> and served as chairman of Plymouth Conservative Club. He was a staunch opponent of vivisection. He was also an <a href="anti-vaccination">anti-vaccination</a>ist and a vice-president of the <a href="National%20Anti-Vaccination%20League">National Anti-Vaccination League</a>.
The front of the pulpit made from granite at <a href="St%20Paul%27s%20Church%2C%20Charlestown">St Paul's Church, Charlestown</a> was gifted by Vawdrey.
Vawdrey died at <a href="East%20Horsley">East Horsley</a>, Surrey.
